dict.string: This is needed to handle the special case of a match against a capitalized type name. Normally a type name may contain => to indicated a function type. But case statements use => to terminate the match expression and thus do not allow function types.
Similar to type-spec, but terminates on =>
Two dollar signs escapes the dollar sign to insert a single dollar sign.
Use only with the f"..." string interpolations
Escapes to insert percent sign or newline
only - flag, width ok, precision not allowed
only - flag, width ok, precision not allowed
only - flag, width ok, precision not allowed
only - flag, width ok, precision not allowed
all flags, width ok, precision ok
all flags, width ok, precision not allowed
For themes: Brackets look nice when colored.
The punctuation.section.*.begin is needed for return snippet in source bundle
The punctuation.section.*.end is needed for return snippet in source bundle
Match special scala style indentifiers that can end with and underscore and a a not letter such as blank_?. This way the symbol will not be colored differently.
Full set of escape sequences permitted in strings
We match """(? for when multi lines are used
We match """(? for when multi lines are used
raw interpolated string only recognize unicode escapes same as triple quoted strings
raw interpolated string only recognize unicode escapes same as triple quoted strings
Unicode escape sequences permitted in triple quoted and raw interpolated strings

We do not allow a tag name to start with a - since this would likely conflict with the <- operator. This is not very common for tag names anyway. Also code such as -- if (val <val2 || val> val3) will falsly be recognized as an xml tag. The solution is to put a space on either side of the comparison operator
